results.title: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.brief_description: The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F. Kennedy on camera in 1963.

constellations_primary.name: Papa-paparazzi
constellations_primary.description: Media attention and paparazzi from the assassination of JFK to Lady Gaga's music video.

results.title_for_label: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.description: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.
description_for_label: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → 05. Camera Tech → MM-05-C01

results.title: Sony Digital Handycam DCR-VX1000
results.brief_description: Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 in 1995, the same year digital video launched. It wasn’t just popular for amateurs and at-home users, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking to replace the large, expensive, shoulder mounted Betacam cameras.

constellations_primary.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.description: Digital video was launched in 1995 and Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 that same year. It was not only hugely popular for the amateur and at-home user, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking for something to replace the large, expensive, shoulder-mounted Betacam cameras. The camcorder was the answer, with high image quality matched by its affordability and portability. These same traits are what saw it became a seminal tool for the creation of skate cinema, with the Handycam DCR-VX1000 often paired with a fish-eye lens and used to record groundbreaking videos in the genre.
description_for_label: Digital video was launched in 1995 and Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 that same year. It was not only hugely popular for the amateur and at-home user, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking for something to replace the large, expensive, shoulder-mounted Betacam cameras. The camcorder was the answer, with high image quality matched by its affordability and portability. These same traits are what saw it became a seminal tool for the creation of skate cinema, with the Handycam DCR-VX1000 often paired with a fish-eye lens and used to record groundbreaking videos in the genre.

results.title: Clapperboard (studio of Mirka Mora)
results.brief_description: Clapperboard made from wood and painted black and white, board has cloth tape around middle and bottom sections. Back of board has a piece of paper attached with rows of numbers.

results.title: Did you ask the river?
results.credit_line:
Joan Ross
Mordant Family VR Commission, ACMI Collection
Developed in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle at Tactical Space Lab, Sydney
results.material_description: software, video, props, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
‘Did you ask the river?’ is the debut VR work from one of Australia’s leading visual artists, Joan Ross.

In the style of a first-person videogame, participants are given free rein to explore an interactive 3D extension of Ross’s vibrant, yet unsettling, colonial landscapes.

Unlike many VR experiences, participants are placed in a body – that of an 18th century colonial woman – and become uncomfortably complicit in her unwitting destruction of the landscape.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Miss Greek Charity Quest]
results.brief_description:
This silent film shows people at the Athenaeum Club in Melbourne celebrating the New Year and finalists of the Miss Greek Charity Quest.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Preparations for Miss Greek Charity Quest]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a small fundraiser and social occasion with Greek youth holding a raffle, barbecue and dance. Money raised supported the Miss Greek Charity Quest, for which the preparations can be seen.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Greek Boy Scouts and Girl Guides supporting Bishop at Festival Hall]
results.brief_description:
This silent film shows the Greek Boy Scouts and other children assembling to celebrate National Day of the Greek Community, 25th March 1966 at Festival Hall, Melbourne.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: TERROR NULLIUS
results.brief_description: Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.
description_for_label:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.

production_dates.notes: Commissioned and exhibited at ACMI for the first time March 20 2018
